title: Cat. 66  Tahitian Girl in a Pink Pareu, 1894
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Tahitian Girl in a Pink Pareu  
1894  
Watercolor monotype from a paper matrix on cream laid paper; 299 × 198 mm  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Edward McCormick Blair, 2002.237  
For the verso, see fig. 66.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Among the most charming of Gauguin’s monotype subjects is a Tahitian girl dressed in a pink pareu. There are four iterations of this image: the gouache and watercolor that served as the matrix (fig. 66.2) and three counterproofs: one in the Art Gallery of Ontario (fig. 66.3) and the two under discussion here.

Françoise Heilbrun was the first to relate the composition to a photograph attributed to the French photographer Charles-Georges Spitz, published in 1886 by the Société de Géographie (fig. 66.4), but perhaps dating a bit earlier. Unlike the model in the photograph, who is nude from the waist up, Gauguin’s figure is covered by a flowered fabric from the neck down. Moreover, as Heilbrun pointed out, Gauguin slightly modified the pose of Spitz’s model: in the gouache, the young woman crosses her hands behind her head more assuredly (and slightly provocatively), which lifts her chest accordingly.

It is difficult to establish a sequence of creation here, but it should be noted that Tahitian Girl in a Pink Pareu (cat. 67) is a cognate of the entire matrix, including the head of a Tahitian man in a lower corner. The Toronto impression retains the firm contour line of the matrix, whereas the present sheet captures more of its color. The dry quality of all three impressions is due to their having been transferred from a work on paper rather than from a metal or glass plate.

Starr Figura suggested that the inclusion of the male profile at the lower edge of the matrix could represent an artist contemplating his model and went on to observe that the relationship between the two is more ambiguous in the other Chicago counterproof on this subject, where the figures appear “more diffuse and illegible.”  
Suzanne Folds McCullagh

Given by Edward McCormick Blair to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">This work is titled La petite Tahitienne en rouge (The Little Tahitian in Pink) in the catalogue raisonné; Georges Wildenstein, Gauguin, with Raymond Cogniat and Daniel Wildenstein, vol. 1, Catalogue (Beaux-Arts, 1964), p. 166, cat. 425. The entry states that the figure does not appear in any previous known work by Gauguin. See also Starr Figura, Gauguin: Metamorphoses, with essays by Elizabeth C. Childs, Hal Foster, and Ericka Mosier, exh. cat. (Museum of Modern Art, New York, 2014), p. 152.

Françoise Heilbrun, in Gauguin Tahiti: L’atelier des tropiques, exh. cat. (Réunion des Musées Nationaux/Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, 2003), p. 59, cat. 37.

In Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973), cat. 22, the author noted that the matrix sheet left an indentation on Tahitian Girl in a Pink Pareu (cat. 67) measuring 265 × 230 mm, dimensions that do not correspond with those of the matrix—244 × 235 mm as published in Starr Figura, Gauguin: Metamorphoses, with essays by Elizabeth C. Childs, Hal Foster, and Ericka Mosier, exh. cat. (Museum of Modern Art, New York, 2014), p. 156, cat. 111.

Starr Figura, Gauguin: Metamorphoses, with essays by Elizabeth C. Childs, Hal Foster, and Ericka Mosier, exh. cat. (Museum of Modern Art, New York, 2014), p. 152.
